CO2 hydrogenation is one of the pivotal approaches to minimizing CO2 emission. As a critical step in converting CO2 into renewable fuels or industrial products, CO2 hydrogenation to CO via reverse water gas shift (RWGS) has received widespread attention and research activities. As a cornerstone of CO2 catalytic utilization, the properties of catalysts play a critical role in determining the catalytic performance. Supported noble metal catalysts have been widely explored in this reaction but designing a catalyst that possesses high activity, decent stability, and good selectivity at low temperature. Herein, a critical review of the advances in supported noble metal catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to CO is presented. Particular attention was made to the structure-performance relationship and strategies to enhance the catalytic behavior of noble metals while also exploring the reaction mechanisms in detail. This review aims to provide an overview and guidelines for the design of stable and efficient supported noble catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to CO in the future. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Reverse water gas shift reaction CO2 hydrogenation to CO Supported noble metal catalyst Catalyst modification Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Climate change and global warming from excessive CO2 emissions are one of the most critical global environmental issues in this century. Increasing efforts are being made to reduce the CO2 emission and improving the efficiency of CO2 capture, storage, and utilization has become an essential direction of current CO2 research [1–6]. Among various CO2 utilization approaches, CO2 hydrogenation by the reverse water gas shift reaction to produce CO is promising. CO can be converted into liquid fuels and other industrial chemicals through the Fischer-Tropsch reaction (as shown in Scheme 1 ) [7–9], methanol carbonylation [10], methyl acetate carbonylation [11], and hydroformylation [12] etc. In addition, the RWGS reaction could play an important role in Mars exploration [13–15]. As CO2 hydrogenation to CO is an endothermic reaction, CO formation is more thermodynamically favorable at higher temperatures. However, high-temperature conditions tend to induce catalyst deactivation such as aggregation, oxidation, and carbon deposition, resulting in lower catalytic behavior [16–18]. Besides, the RWGS reaction is often accompanied by the formation of by-products such as CH4, especially at low temperatures, where the thermodynamics is more conducive to CO2 methanation than the RWGS reaction [19,20]. Therefore, it is desirable to develop RWGS catalysts with high activity, selectivity, and stability. The catalysts for the RWGS reaction can be divided into three main categories: supported catalysts, oxide catalysts, and carbide catalysts [3]. Supported catalysts are the most widely studied catalysts for the RWGS reaction due to the dual functionality of CO2 synergistic activation and H2 dissociation. The RWGS reaction is a structure-sensitive reaction where the catalytic behavior of supported catalysts is affected by the structural and electronic properties of the metal and supports, such as the particle size, the dispersion of the active metal component, the shape and crystal plane of supports, and the acidity and alkalinity [21]. Supported noble-metal catalysts (such as Au, Pt, and Pd) showed excellent catalytic performance in RWGS reaction, but the low reserves and high prices limit the large-scale application. On the other hand, non-noble metal catalysts including Cu, Ni, Fe, Co, Mo, etc., were low in cost but the CO2 conversion at low temperatures still needs much improvement, and the active species tend to aggregate at high temperatures [22,23]. Several reviews have summarized the recent progress of the RWGS reaction. Yolanda et al. listed the types of catalysts, catalytic mechanisms, and the implications in CO2 conversion processes [19]. Similarly, Su et al. also presented a comprehensive overview of the reaction thermodynamic analysis, kinetics, catalytic performance, and mechanisms of RWGS reaction over three kinds of heterogeneous catalysts [20]. After that, Chen et al. [21] and Zhu et al. [24]. systematically reported the effects of physicochemical properties on the catalytic performance in the RWGS over supported catalysts. The literature of Zhang et al. [25] and Pahija et al. [26] were more detailed, where they summarized the progress of transition metal carbides (TMCs) and experimental and computational synergistic design of Cu and Fe catalysts, respectively. In this review, an overview of the recent progress in the development of supported noble catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to CO is presented. The relationships between the particle size, metal-support interaction, oxygen vacancies, reducibility of support, acid-basic property, element doping, and the catalytic performance of catalysts in CO2 are systematically presented. Besides, the reaction mechanism that was studied using theoretical and experimental in the literature is also reviewed. The challenges and future opportunities of supported noble-metal catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation to CO are proposed at the end. 2 Reaction mechanism The reaction mechanism of the RWGS reaction consists of two main types: redox mechanism and association mechanism [19,21,24,26,27]. The difference between these two mechanisms is whether the dissociated H species are involved in the formation of carbon-containing intermediates (e.g., formate, carboxylate, etc.). 2.1 Redox mechanism The redox mechanism means that the reaction is carried out through circulating redox sites on the catalyst surface, and there are usually two types of redox sites: metal sites that are variable in valence state and oxygen vacancies [28]. However, noble metal elements are usually stable and the valence state is not easily varied, so the redox mechanism of noble metal catalysts takes surface oxygen vacancies as the main sites [29]. The CO2 adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies on the oxide surface dissociates to form CO, and then the activated dissociated H species combines with the oxygen on the oxygen vacancies to form H2O and regenerates the oxygen vacancies to complete the whole redox process. The proposed reactions are shown below: (1) C O 2 + O v → C O + O * (2) H 2 + 2 * → H * + H * (3) 2 H * + O * → H 2 O + O v Rabee et al. proposed a redox mechanism involving oxygen vacancies as shown in Fig. 1 by studying the mechanism of the RWGS reaction of Au/TiO2 [30]. The analysis of the characterization results such as X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) showed that on the surface of TiO2, an electron-rich Au favoring CO2 dissociation and activation was formed, along with the presence of Ti3+ species and oxygen vacancies. In addition, the results of electron energy loss spectroscopy revealed that Ti3+ was mainly formed in the shell layer region of TiO2 particles. These results suggested that the Ov-Ti3+ site was involved in the reaction mechanism. The Au-Ov-T3+ was the active site responsible for CO2 activation and conversion to CO, and CO2 molecules were first activated at the Au-Ov-Ti3+ site. The activated CO2 molecules were subsequently hydrogenated to hydroxycarbonyl (OCOH) species. Due to the relatively short lifetime of OCOH species, they rapidly decomposed into weakly adsorbed CO and OH on the Au surface. Eventually, the adsorbed H and OH reacted with H2O to generate oxygen vacancies. 2.2 Association mechanism The formate pathway means that the CO2 adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst reacted with the dissociated H species to form HCOO intermediate, which further hydrogenated and decomposed to CO and OH. Then OH continued to react with the H species to form H2O. The proposed reaction is shown below: (4) CO 2 + O v → CO 2 * (5) H 2 + 2 * → H * + H * (6) CO 2 * + H * → HCO O * (7) HCO O * → C O * + O H * (8) C O * → CO + O v (9) O H * + H * → H 2 O Bobadilla et al. investigated the reaction mechanism of RWGS on Au/Al2O3 [29]. The transient diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) experiments were first performed under transient conditions to explore the formation of surface species on Au/Al2O3 catalysts under operando conditions. The characteristic peaks at 1229,1437 and 1647cm−1 of DRIFT spectra proved the formation of surface bicarbonate, which was generated by the reaction of CO2 with the hydroxyl group on the Al2O3 support. After switching from the CO2 flow to the H2 flow, a new energy band representing the formate species adsorbed on Al2O3 appeared. The presence of the isosbestic point at ∼1600 cm−1 indicated the conversion of bicarbonate to formate. The surface species during the RWGS reaction at 250 °C were subsequently studied by DRIFTS. It showed that the RWGS reaction mechanism catalyzed by Au/Al2O3 was as follows (Fig. 2 ). CO2 reacted with the hydroxyl group on Al2O3 to generate bicarbonate firstly, and the dissociation of H2 occurred on Au. The dissociated H species spilled over to Al2O3 and reacted with bicarbonate to form formate, and finally the formate decomposed to CO and H2O. 3 Supported noble metal catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to CO Noble metals exhibit excellent catalytic activity and CO selectivity for RWGS reactions due to their outstanding ability to dissociate H2, unique d-orbital electronic properties, and moderate adsorption strength for reaction intermediates [22,31]. In addition, compared to non-noble metals, noble metals show excellent resistance to sintering, oxidation, and corrosion, exhibiting exceptional stability [32]. Among the commonly used noble metals (such as Au, Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru, and Ir), Pt and Rh show higher H2 dissociation activity than Au. Rh and Ru exhibit higher selectivity for CH4 generation. Besides, Pd displays a high energy barrier for CO2 dissociation, and has a strong affinity for hydrogen. The commonly used supports include Al2O3, SiO2, ZrO2, CeO2, TiO2, and MoOx. In recent years, some new supports like SrTiO3, samarium-doped ceria (SDC), alloy supports, and TMCs have also been widely studied. This section summarizes the recent advances of noble metal-based (Au, Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru, and Ir) catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation to CO. The role of supports, supported metal particle size, oxygen vacancies, core-shell structure, metal doping, and hydroxyl groups on the activity and selectivity was highlighted. 3.1 Au-based catalysts Compared with Pt and Rh, bulk Au filled with d-orbital electrons showed lower activity for H2 dissociation and therefore lower hydrogenation capacity [20]. However, when the particle size decreased to the nanoscale, Au species showed excellent catalytic hydrogenation performance [33–36]. Current studies on Au-based catalysts focus on investigating the reaction mechanism, the effect of Au particle dispersion, and the promoter on the catalytic activity in RWGS reactions. Commonly used supports for Au-based catalysts include Al2O3 [29], CeO2 [37–40], TiO2 [29,30,41,42], ZrO2 [30,43,44], SiO2 [45], metal-organic framework (MOF) [42], and TMCs [46–49]. CO2 conversions and product selectivity over various Au-based catalysts under specific conditions including temperature, pressure, H2/CO2 ratio, and space velocity are listed in Table 1 . 3.1.1 Support effect The catalytic activity of Au-based catalysts is directly related to the properties of the support. Sakurai et al. investigated the effect of the acid-base property of the support on the Au-based catalytic activity and revealed that the catalytic activity of Au nanoparticles loaded on acidic supports was higher than that of those loaded on basic supports since acidic supports showed weaker adsorption for CO2, thus prohibiting CO2 poisoning on active sites [50]. The catalytic activity of Au-based catalysts is also closely related to the formation of intermediates and reaction pathways. Bobadilla et al. investigated the mechanism of the RWGS reaction for Au/Al2O3 and Au/TiO2 catalysts [29]. According to the result of DRIFTS, it was found that the reaction proceeded via a formate intermediate pathway over Au/Al2O3 (Fig. 3 a). However, the reaction over Au/TiO2 occurred through a redox mechanism at a lower temperature to produce hydroxycarbonyl intermediates (Fig. 3b), which further decomposed to CO and water. The Ti3+ species, surface hydroxyl groups, and oxygen vacancies were synergistically involved in this process, in agreement with the results of Rabee et al. [30]. As the desorption and/or decomposition of formate and carbonate occurred rapidly at high temperatures, the carbonate/formate pathway would dominate. Apart from oxide supports, TMCs such as Mo2C, TiC, WC, and VC were also used to disperse metal particles and improve the ability of the catalysts to absorb and dissociate CO2. TMCs show similar electronic properties to noble metals and exhibit similar catalytic properties to noble metals in hydrogenation and dehydrogenation reactions [25,51–53]. They can be used not only as catalysts but also as excellent supports for catalysts used in the RWGS reaction [54–56]. It was reported that Au/δ-MoC catalysts exhibited high activity, selectivity, and stability in both the conversion of CO2 to CO and further hydrogenation of CO to methanol [49]. Au/TiC showed excellent CO2 activation and H2 dissociation ability [48]. Rodriguez et al. investigated that Au/TiC can generate CO via the RWGS reaction with HOCO as the main reaction intermediate, but it will also generate CH3OH via the HCOO intermediate or further hydrogenation of CO [46,47]. The size and stacking mode of Au had an influence on the reaction, with H2 more easily dissociated on small-sized Au particles. In addition, the two-dimensional Au clusters were more capable of binding to the TiC surface, and due to the interaction between Au and TiC surface leading to polarization and electron transfer, the two-dimensional Au clusters were more capable of CO2 and H2 adsorption and better at dissociating CO2 than the three-dimensional Au clusters. 3.1.2 Oxygen vacancies Rabee et al. investigated the reaction mechanism of Au/TiO2 and Au/ZrO2 catalysts, and found that the formation of highly dispersed Au nanoparticles, oxygen vacancies on the surface of the support, and readily decomposable intermediates were key factors in determining the catalytic activity of Au-based catalysts [30].The Au/TiO2 formed Auδ−-Ov-Ti3+ active sites, which accelerated CO formation through hydroxycarbonyl intermediates. However, the predominant mechanism over Au/ZrO2 was the formate mechanism, where CO2 was strongly adsorbed in the oxygen vacancies, and CO was released through the formation of formate species. Zhu et al. explored the reaction mechanism of Au/CeO2 catalyst, and showed that Au/CeO2 also formed CO through formate intermediates [37]. Ziemba et al. compared the effect of CeO2 supports and pretreatment conditions on the catalytic activity and pathway of Au/CeO2 catalysts RWGS reaction [40]. It was reported that the concentration of surface defects on the support had little effect on the reaction rate, while pretreatment conditions significantly affected the type of intermediates, thus altering the catalytic activity and pathway. The associative mechanism through carbonate and formate intermediates was the main pathway of the Au/CeO2-catalyzed RWGS reaction, while the redox mechanism played only a minor role. 3.1.3 Transition metal oxide promoters The addition of oxide promoters to Au-based catalysts remarkably generated new active sites and increased the catalytic activity in the RWGS reaction. Carrasquillo-Flores et al. added MoOx to Au/SiO2 to investigate the relationship between RWGS reactivity and surface Au site coordination [45]. It was reported that the catalyst calcination increased the number of under-coordinated Au sites for AuMo/SiO2 catalyst. This was supported with Raman spectrum of Mo/SiO2 which showed a feature peak at 975 cm−1 assigned to a dioxo (O=)2Mo(-OSi)2 that was not observed in the AuMo/SiO2 catalyst spectrum, indicating that Mo was preferentially deposited on Au. The X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) results showed that Au was in metallic state, and Mo was in the oxidation state of +6, indicating that Au and Mo appeared as a combination of metal-metal oxides form. Combined with the results of X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and CO-Fourier Transform infrared spectroscopy (CO-FTIR), it was demonstrated that the deposition of Mo on Au nanoparticles occurred preferentially on the under-coordinated Au sites, forming Au/MoOx interfacial sites that were more active for the RWGS reaction. 3.1.4 Porous or core-shell structure Sintering and rapid deactivation of catalysts at high temperatures are serious problems for Au-based catalytic systems. Xu et al. prepared Au/UIO-67 using Zr(IV)-based porous MOFs (UIO-67) as support, the synthetic strategy and the N2 isotherms of Au@UIO-67 were shown in Fig. 4 a and b, respectively [42]. The thermally stable UIO-67 support with high specific surface area and high porosity was conducive to the adsorption of gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) into the outer pores or cavities of UIO-67 to obtain monodisperse and isolated metal nanoparticles (NPs), avoiding the sintering and aggregation of metal nanoparticles, thus improving the performance of the RWGS reaction. However, when the Au NPs loading was high, the overcrowding of Au NPs increased the possibility of migration and sintering and reduced the CO2 conversion (Fig. 4c). Later, Xu et al. made further improvements and prepared spherically intercalated Au@Pd@UIO-67/Pt@UIO-n (n = 66, 67, 69) core-shell catalysts by doping with Pd and Pt [57]. The synthetic strategy for Au@Pd@UIO-67/Pt@UIO-n NPs and its structure can be seen in Fig. 4d. The bimetallic Au@Pd core-shell was located at the center of the NPs, while Pt was well dispersed between the Au@Pd@UIO-67 core and UIO-67 shell. C, O, and Zr elements in UIO-67 were uniformly distributed throughout the NPs. The Au@Pd core-shell NPs effectively controlled the morphology and structure of UIO-67 and improved the CO selectivity (Fig. 4e). Besides, Pt NPs enhanced the conversion of CO2 and the UIO-n component effectively regulated the RWGS reaction. As shown in Table 1, the catalysts with a porous or core-shell structure exhibited higher catalytic efficiency under the same reaction conditions compared to other types of catalysts, demonstrating the superiority of this structure. 3.2 Pt-based catalysts Supported Pt-based catalysts exhibited high H2 dissociation ability at low reaction temperatures and relatively moderate adsorption strength to reaction intermediates, thus showing excellent catalytic activity and stability [59–61]. Pt-based catalysts have been studied as RWGS catalysts for decades. However, Pt-based catalysts often fail to possess both high CO2 conversion and high CO selectivity (especially at higher reaction temperatures), which is a pressing problem in current Pt-based catalysts research [61,1,62]. Commonly used support materials include Al2O3 [63,64], CeO2 [59,1,65–67], TiO2 [62,63,68–70], Fe3O4 [71], SrTiO3 [72], SiO2 [60,62,73], zeolite [61,74], mullite [75], etc. Table 2 summarized the catalytic performance of Pt-based catalysts in RWGS reaction. 3.2.1 The reducibility of supports CO2 could be activated on the clean single crystal Pt(111) surface by the dissociation mechanism to form adsorbed CO and O at room temperature or high temperature [76]. After introducing H2, the adsorbed O was continuously consumed to form H2O, and the adsorbed CO was desorbed from the surface at high temperatures. When Pt was loaded on the oxide support, CO2 activation occurred on the oxide support, while H2 dissociation occurred on Pt particles [65]. The catalytic activity varied depending on oxide supports, mainly due to the different interactions between the supports and Pt [24]. In general, reducible supports such as TiO2 and CeO2 showed higher CO2 conversion in the RWGS reaction than non-reducible supports like SiO2 and Al2O3. TiO2 and CeO2 exhibited strong interactions with the loaded Pt to provide oxygen vacancies, which had a strong adsorption effect on CO2 and could directly activate CO2, thus facilitating the RWGS reaction. On the other hand, SiO2 and Al2O3 mainly play a dispersing role and cannot activate CO2 directly. Loading Pt on reducible oxide supports effectively enhanced the reduction of the supports and promoted the formation of oxygen vacancies to accelerate the activation of CO2, such as Pt/CeO2 [65,67]. New active interfacial sites such as Pt-O-Mn+ at the Pt-oxide interface were selective for the formation of CO [63]. For instance, Pt-Ov-Ti3+ sites (Ov = oxygen vacancy) generated by the interaction of Pt with reducible TiO2 support were active sites for CO generation [68,77]. Therefore, the CO2 reduction selectivity of Pt/TiO2 catalysts effectively regulated by modulating the types of active sites in Pt-based catalysts. Wang et al. explored the interfacial structure of Pt/SiO2 catalyst in RWGS reactions [73]. In the presence of H2, the Si at the PtSiO2 interface was reduced, which further diffused to the near Pt nanoparticles. This reconstructed PtSi interface improved the sintering resistance and catalytic stability of Pt nanoparticles. The density functional theory (DFT) simulation of CO2 hydrogenation on the PtSi surface indicated that the energy barrier for the activation of intermediate species on the PtSi site was lower, further proving that the PtSi surface provided a synergistic site for the activation of CO2/H2 to generate CO (Fig. 5 a and 5b). 3.2.2 The dispersion of Pt The particle size and dispersion of Pt species can affect the catalytic activity of Pt-based catalysts by influencing the further hydrogenation process of CO [66,72,78–80]. Zhao et al. synthesized three types of Pt/CeO2 catalysts, including atomically dispersed Pt, Pt clusters, and nanoparticles [66]. In the range of 200–450 °C, the atomically dispersed Pt/CeO2 catalyst showed significant CO selectivity (> 98 %), while the CO selectivity of Pt nanoparticles decreased with the increase in reaction temperature. The results of CO-temperature programmed desorption (CO-TPD) and in situ FTIR CO desorption experiments showed that the adsorption of CO was stronger for Pt nanoparticles than atomically dispersed Pt, which further facilitated the excessive hydrogenation of CO to form CH4. The adsorption strength of atomically dispersed Pt was relatively weak for CO, thus preventing excessive hydrogenation. Therefore, atomically dispersed Pt was essential to prevent the excessive hydrogenation of CO and thus improve CO selectivity. Xing et al. supported this conclusion in their study of Pt/SrTiO3 catalyst, where they found that the single Pt atoms were active in the RWGS reaction through a formate intermediate reaction mechanism, while larger Pt clusters and nanoparticles promoted further hydrogenation of CO and showed lower CO selectivity [72]. The reaction and pretreatment environment affected the activity of single-atom catalysts (SACs), and the lack of understanding of the process of SACs occurred under the reaction and pretreatment conditions hindered the in-depth understanding and subsequent application of SACs [81,82]. To address this issue, Chen et al. reported a reduction-oxidation activation system, in which the catalyst was first reduced in H2 and subsequently oxidized in O2 [79]. As shown in the result of extended x-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), the low catalytic activity for the fresh SACs was attributed to the high PtO coordination (Fig. 5c), which limited the accessibility of Pt interatomic (Pt1). The reduction step facilitated Pt1 to form aggregates that were small, amorphous and unstable. The reoxidation step redispersed Pt nanoparticles into Pt1 in a new environment with a low O coordination environment, making the single metal atoms more accessible and active (Fig. 5d and 5e). After cyclic treatment, Pt/TiO2 SACs exhibited superior catalytic activity than non-atomically dispersed Pt/TiO2 for the RWGS reaction (Fig. 5f). During the RWGS reaction, activated Pt1 underwent slow deactivation, but could be reactivated by mild oxidation. Atomically dispersed Pt do not always show better RWGS activity than Pt clusters or nanoparticles. Zhang et al. reported a high-performance catalyst PtNC/LOC for the RWGS reaction consisting of ultrafine Pt clusters (average 1.38 nm) anchored by La2O2CO3 support [83]. The catalyst showed a CO yield of 2678 molCO·molPt −1·h−1 at 300 °C with CO selectivity close to 100 %. Moreover, the specific activities of PtNC/LOC were approximately 1.5 and 7.9 times higher than those of single-atom Pt and nanoparticles on La2O2CO3, respectively. The structure was stable with more than 87.7 % of initial activity after 80 h of reaction at 380 °C. The excellent performance of PtNC/LOC was attributed to its weak adsorption capacity of CO (Fig. 5g) and the ability to generate more oxygen vacancies for the enhanced adsorption of CO2 (Fig. 5h). The relationship between CO formation rate with CO desorption and CO2 adsorption was shown in Fig. 5i. In addition, the moderate basicity of the LOC support improved the reaction efficiency, and its strong interaction with Pt species maintained the ultrafine particle size. Further studies pointed out the key role of Pt clusters. The two key steps of CO2 adsorption and CO desorption were associated with electron-rich and electron-deficient Pt species, respectively. The ultra-small Pt clusters combined the unique surface states of single atoms and nanoparticles to achieve super low-temperature RWGS performance. 3.2.3 Transition metal or oxide promoters Similar to Au-based catalysts, the addition of oxides such as CeO2 [70] and MoOx [84,85] to Pt-based catalysts also improved catalytic activity for the RWGS reaction. The doping of CeO2 into Pt/TiO2 affected the lattice and pore structure through the substitution of TiO2, which further promoted the catalytic activity [70]. Mine et al. compared the catalytic activity of 3 % Pt/TiO2 with 3 % Pt/15 % MoOx/TiO2 catalysts for the RWGS reaction at 300 °C [84]. As shown in Table 2, with the addition of MoOx, the CO2 conversion of the catalyst increased from 5 % to 6.9 % and the CO selectivity enhanced from 96.8 % to 99.2 %. During the reaction, H2 reduced some of the MoOx species oxidized by CO2, which further generated oxygen vacancies and promoted the production of CO through the reverse Mars van Krevelen mechanism. Liu et al. further explained the influence of the interaction between Pt and MoOx on the catalysts [85]. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) and Roman spectra analysis of 0.5Pt-MoO3/ Mo2N showed that the MoO3 structure could be reduced to MoOx (2 < x < 3). The Pt atoms were bonded with oxygen atoms of MoOx to form stable Pt clusters, and these high densities of Ptn-Ov active sites obviously promoted the catalytic activity. Furthermore, the interaction between Pt and MoOx prevented the sintering of Pt clusters and kept the catalysts with excellent stability. The doping of other metal elements into Pt-based catalysts can improve the catalytic activity of the RWGS reaction and the CO selectivity while using less noble metal. The doped metal elements that have been studied include Fe [86], Re [60], W [87], Ni [88–90] and Co [1,91]. Wang et al. doped Fe into Pt/CeO2 and constructed Fe-Pt/CeO2 hetero-dual-site catalyst, which exhibited high RWGS catalytic performance at 350 °C with CO selectivity close to 100 % (Fig. 6 a and 6b) [86]. DFT calculations (Fig. 6c) showed that in the process of converting formate intermediates to CO*, Fe-Pt/CeO2 and Pt/CeO2 needed to overcome the energy barriers of 1.33 and 1.48 eV, respectively. Fe-Pt/CeO2 exhibited a lower energy barrier, indicating a higher RWGS activity. Combining the experiments with other characterizations such as DRIFTS shown in Fig. 6d, a "two-way synergistic effect" was revealed, in which the Fe atom could not only act as a promoter to change the charge density of the Pt atom but also be activated by the excess active hydrogen produced by the Pt atom, making it an active site for the conversion of reactive intermediate and improving the catalytic activity and stability (Fig. 6e). Liu et al. prepared Pt-Re/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts with 1 wt% Pt and different Re dosages for the RWGS reaction [60]. XRD and transmission electron microscope (TEM) results showed that the addition of 0.5 wt% Re reduced the Pt particle size. Moreover, the oxophilic ReOx (0 ≤ x ≤ 3.5) was located near the Pt particles and modified the Pt surface through partial coverage and electronic interactions, which led to a decrease in number of sites for CO adsorption and weakening of the adsorption strength. The reaction order analysis showed that Pt favored the activation of H2, while the oxophilic ReOx favored the adsorption and activation of CO2. The sites with equilibrium hydrogenation and CO cleavage properties at the Pt/ReOx interface synergistically enhanced the RWGS reaction activity while inhibiting the formation of CH4, maintaining >96.2 % CO selectivity under overall conditions (Table 2). Kobayashi et al. found that the alloying of Pt with W could effectively enhance the Pt nanoparticle activity, improve the sintering resistance of Pt nanoparticles and promote the adsorption of CO2 and desorption of CO from the catalyst [87]. PtW NPs/Al2O3 exhibited 16∼17 times higher catalytic activity than Pt/Al2O3 at low temperatures of 200 °C and 300 °C. In addition, PtW NPs/Al2O3 showed high durability and excellent catalytic properties. 3.2.4 N-doping or alkali metal modification Apart from transition metal or metal oxides, non-metal elements such as N were also employed to promote the activity of Pt-based catalysts in RWGS. Chen et al. prepared Pt/TiO2 N by doping N into Pt/TiO2, which exhibited superior catalytic performance and CO selectivity of the RWGS reaction [69]. Further studies showed that surface oxygen vacancies and doped-N promoted Pt dispersion and prevented Pt sintering during calcination and reduction. In addition, more electrons were transferred from TiO2 to the surface Pt species due to N-doping, enhancing the SMSI effect between Pt and N-doped TiO2. Both H2 reduction and N-doping promoted the generation of surface and bulk defects of TiO2 support. Besides, Pt particles and SMSI also promoted the reduction of TiO2 support, generating more surface and bulk defects during H2 activation. The surface defects adsorbed CO2 to form active intermediates that were easily decomposed into CO, while Pt particles activated H2 to form active H atoms to supplement surface and bulk defects. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 6f and g, N-doped TiO2 had more stable bulk Ti3+, which easily migrated to the surface in the reducing atmosphere and further replenished the consumed surface defects to improve the catalytic performance. The RWGS reaction process over the N-doped Pt/TiO2 catalyst was illustrated in Fig. 6h. The addition of alkali metals to Pt-based catalysts was also reported to significantly improve the catalytic performance. Alkali metals can be used as structural or electronic promoters, and increase the alkalinity to improve the adsorption capacity for acidic CO2. In addition, the selectivity of the product can be modulated by adding alkali metals [92]. Santos et al. doped Na into biochar-based Pt catalysts and the results showed that the presence of Na changed the interaction between Pt sites and carbon supports in the RWGS reaction [93]. The promoting effect mainly originated from the modulating of the electronic structure of Pt particles, and this electronic perturbation changed the chemical behavior of the Pt particles, generating new sites favorable for CO2 dissociation. The controlled addition of K promoter by KOH impregnation of Pt/zeolite-L catalyst generated new active sites Pt-O(OH)-K, which promoted the formation of formate intermediates and enhanced the catalytic activity and CO selectivity [61]. Liang et al. demonstrated that the K promoter enhanced the adsorption of CO2 and reduced the CO adsorption to hinder further hydrogenation of CO to CH4 through CO bond dissociation [75]. 3.3 Pd-based catalysts The catalytic performance of Pd species supported on CeO2 [94], SiO2 [97], FeOx [97], Al2O3 [98–101], Ga2O3 [102], ZnOx [103], TiO2 [104], and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) [99] were also evaluated in RWGS reaction. The CO2 dissociation barrier on Pd(111) was the highest among a series of studied single-crystal metal surfaces [105]. However, the low-pressure (100 m Torr) CO2 dissociated on the surface of Pd(111) via the RWGS reaction when H2 was introduced [106]. Choi et al. investigated the catalytic behavior of different metals supported on Al2O3 for the high-temperature RWGS reaction [101]. The results indicated that Pd/Al2O3 had the highest CO2 conversion activity. Arunajatesan et al. reported that Pd dispersed on Al2O3 could promote the dissociative adsorption of H2 to form active H atoms, which spilled over to the support and reacted with the carbonate to form formate and CO [98]. The RWGS activity of recent developed Pd-based catalysts are listed in Table 3 . 3.3.1 Pd particle size The particle size of Pd had a significant effect on the catalytic activity. Wang et al. explored the catalytic performance and reaction mechanism of Pd/Al2O3 catalysts with different Pd particle sizes via a combination of in situ DRIFT spectroscopy and mass spectrometry techniques (MS) [100]. They demonstrated that the Pd particle size did not affect the mechanistic sequence of the surface species during CO2 hydrogenation. The hydroxyl groups on the surface of Al2O3 reacted with CO2 to form bicarbonate, which subsequently underwent hydrogenation with H species formed by dissociative adsorption of H2 on Pd to produce formate, and finally converted to CO. On the other hand, the catalytic performance was closely related to the particle size of Pd species. The activity test of 0.5 % Pd/γ-Al2O3 and 5 % Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalysts showed that the selectivity of 5 % Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for CH4 (22∼40 %) was 2∼3 times higher than that of 0.5 % Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. On the surface of smaller Pd particles, Pd sites that barely bind CO surface species formed through formate intermediates were more prevalent and showed higher selectivity for CO, while larger Pd particles were more likely to form Pd sites that bound more CO, which then interacted strongly with adsorbed H atoms, resulting in higher rates and selectivity for the CO methanation process. Kwak et al. reported different catalytic performances of atomically dispersed Pd and conventional 3D Pd clusters, and studied the catalytic mechanism and product distribution of the RWGS reaction on Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/MWCNT catalysts [99]. The results showed that CO2 reduction required a catalytic active component (Al2O3 or La2O3) that activated CO2, and the presence of a metal component (Pd) capable of dissociating H2. When both functions were present, the selectivity of CO and CH4 was dependent on the size of the metal particles. The thermodynamic stability of single-atom Pd loaded on Pd1/TiO2 catalysts for the RWGS reaction was attributed to the stabilization of the enthalpy of the Ov site formed in situ during RWGS and the increase in the flat-motion entropy of the Pd attached atoms after TiO2 conditioning (Fig. 7 a and 7b) [104]. 3.3.2 Bimetallic effect Combining Pd with other elements to form bimetallic nanoparticles was another strategy to improve the selectivity of CO generation [107]. As listed in Table 3. compared to Pd/SiO2 (∼35 % CO selectivity at 500 °C, Pd-In/SiO2 showed 100 % selectivity for CO but lower CO yield. This phenomenon was attributed to (i) the lower activity of PdIn for H2 dissociation than Pd (Fig. 7c), (ii) the much weaker binding of CO on the PdIn surface than on the Pd surface (Fig. 7d), and (iii) increased the barrier of CO hydrogenation on PdIn surface. Fig. 7e and f showed the DRIFTS spectra of CO adsorption on Pd-In/SiO2 and Pd/SiO2, where the adsorption bands at 2171 and 2127 cm−1 indicated the gas-phase CO, while the peaks at 2094 and 1975 cm−1 represented the linear and bridge-bonded CO on PdIn bimetallic particles, respectively. By comparing the changes in band intensity with time, it was concluded that the CO adsorption on Pdln bimetallic particles was weaker than that on Pd. 3.4 Rh-based catalysts Similar to Pt, supported Rh-based catalysts also exhibit high H2 dissociation activity, relatively moderate adsorption strength for reaction intermediates, and catalyze RWGS reaction via the redox mechanism [109]. Compared to Pt, Rh-based catalysts are more selective for CH4 [110–113], and the selectivity of the product is closely related to the support material [59]. The support of Rh-based catalysts that have been studied include TiO2 [81,114,115], Al2O3 [112,116,117], SiO2 [118,119], CeO2 [120,121], Fe2O3 [120], SrTiO3 [122], W6S8 [123], Mo6S8 [124], zeolite [125], ZrO2 [126,127], MgO [126] etc. The selection of suitable supports and regulating the structure of Rh-based catalysts to improve the selectivity for CO were the focuses of the studies (Table 4 ). 3.4.1 Hydroxyl groups The concentration of hydroxyl groups had a significant effect on the catalytic activity of Rh-based catalysts. Hitoshi Kusama et al. investigated the effect of hydroxyl groups on the catalytic activity of CO2 hydrogenation over Rh/SiO2 catalysts [119]. Three precursors, including Rh(CH3COO)3, Rh(NO3)3 and RhCl3·3H2O were applied to prepared the samples. The results indicated that the main products of catalysts prepared from Rh(CH3COO)3 and Rh(NO3)3 precursors were CO, while the catalyst prepared from RhCl3·3H2O dominantly produced CH4. They further revealed that the activity difference was due to the hydroxyl groups. In the catalysts prepared from Rh(CH3COO)3 precursor, the Rh particles were surrounded by a large number of SiO2 hydroxyl groups, which reacted with CO-saturated Rh species produced by CO2 dissociative adsorption, and then the produced CO desorbed as molecular CO without further hydrogenation. On the other hand, in the catalysts prepared by RhCl3·3H2O, only a small amount of SiO2 surface hydroxyl groups existed around the Rh particles, which were unable to form Rh carbonyl clusters. The presence of more hydride species and less CO on the Rh surface led to the formation of CH4. In addition, Hitoshi Kusama et al. found that the selectivity for CO decreased with the increase of Rh loading on the Rh/SiO2 catalyst [118]. As a result, Rh particles at low concentrations were easily surrounded by SiO2 hydroxyl groups to form Rh carbonyl clusters. 3.4.2 Rh dispersion The size and dispersion of Rh nanoparticles have an important effect on the selectivity of Rh-based catalysts. It was shown that catalysts loaded with highly dispersed Rh nanoparticles exhibited higher catalytic activity for RWGS reaction [81,114,115,120–123,128]. The higher selectivity for the RWGS reaction of the atomically dispersed Rh1 supported on TiO2 compared to the larger Rhx (x = 2∼8 atoms) nanoclusters was attributed to the higher energy barrier for CO bond dissociation and weaker CO adsorption on Rh1/TiO2 [115]. As shown in Fig. 8 a, the binding energy of CO on Rh1 (−1.82 eV) was lower than that of other Rh nanoclusters (−3.33∼−2.35 eV). In addition, Rh1 showed a higher activation barrier to dissociate H2 than Rh2 dimers or nanoclusters (Fig. 8b), and had limited Rh-metal sites to adsorb H* for the further reduction of adsorbed CO to CH4. Yan et al. reported that the higher CO selectivity of Rh/SrTiO3 catalysts loaded with highly dispersed Rh clusters was attributed to the strong interaction (e.g., charge transfer) between Rh atoms and oxide supports with surface defects, thus resulting in weaker binding of CO on Rh [122]. Tang et al. systematically explored the local coordination environment of Rh single atoms on Rh1/TiO2 catalysts and demonstrated that Rh single atoms adjusted their local coordination and reactivity in different redox conditions [81]. Rh1/TiO2 catalysts transformed from inactive to active structures under reaction conditions. The changes in the oxidation state and coordination environment were driven by the OH on the TiO2 surface and the formation of oxygen vacancies. 3.4.3 Alkali or transition metal doping Li et al. doped Na+ in Rh1/ZrO2 and found that the reaction pathway was completely changed from methanation to RWGS reaction [127]. The catalysts (e.g., 1 % Na-Rh1/ZrO2) also exhibited excellent long-term stability and catalytic activity. The DRIFTS characterization results (Fig. 8c) and Gibbs free energy profiles of CO2 activation on ZrO2 and Na-doped ZrO2 (Fig. 8f and 8 g) showed that Na+ on the surface of ZrO2 changed the reaction intermediate (from HCOO* to COOH*) and enhanced the adsorption of CO2 and COOH* on ZrO2 by forming Na-O bonds, thus promoting the formation of CO. Meanwhile, Na+ enhanced the interaction between Rh1 and ZrO2, decreased the electron density of Rh1 atoms, promoted the desorption of CO (Fig. 8d), and inhibited H2 activation ability (Fig. 8e), thus achieving an effective regulation of CO selectivity over a wide temperature range and improving the sintering resistance of the catalyst. Robert Büchel et al. doped K into Rh/Al2O3 catalyst and explored the structure-performance relationship [112]. As shown in Table 4, the pure Rh/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited high CH4 selectivity below 500 °C, with the highest yield at 400 °C, while the RWGS reaction gradually became dominant above 400 °C. In contrast, Rh/Al2O3-K catalyst maintained 100 % CO selectivity over the temperature range of 300∼800 °C. However, the doping of K did not enhance the catalytic activity of the catalysts, presumably attributed to the high stability of the carbonate intermediate at the optimum reaction temperature. Heyl et al. reported that K promotion in RhNiK/Al2O3 catalyst reduced adsorption strength of formate allowing for more reactive CO intermediate formation. The K addition also promoted CO desorption while decreasing the H2 dissociation by Rh, promoting CO formation [111]. These results indicated that the use of alkali metal ions to synergistically modulate the metal atoms and supports electronically and structurally was an effective way to design Rh-based catalysts with tunable catalytic properties. Gogate et al. reported that the selectivity for CO in the Rh/TiO2 catalyst was improved from 14.5 % to 28.4 % after Fe doping (T = 270 °C, P = 2 MPa, H2: CO2 = 1:1) [129]. Kim et al. demonstrated that the Fe doping in CeO2 promoted the mobility of oxygen on the support surface. When Rh was loaded on Fe-CeO2 and reduced, a permeable shell was formed on the Rh nanoparticles, which can effectively enhance the catalytic activity and durability [120]. The weaker adsorption of CO by the encapsulated Rh nanoparticles and the increased spillover of H2 on Fe-CeO2 resulted in a catalyst with high activity for the RWGS reaction, high yields within all temperature ranges, and a significant increase in catalyst durability. 3.5 Ru-based catalysts Ru-based catalysts were initially considered methanation and methanolation catalysts due to their ability to bind and dissociate CO [131,132]. Ru has a few oxidation states and embodies similar electronic properties when combined with oxide supports or transition metals, so it is also used in RWGS reactions [133–135]. Ru is one of the most economical among noble metals. Therefore, improving the catalytic activity and CO selectivity of Ru-based catalysts for RWGS reactions is an important direction of current research. As shown in Table 5 , the commonly used support for Ru-based catalysts include CeO2 [134], Al2O3 [133,136,137], TiO2 [138,139], ZrO2 [140], MnO [141], ZnO [142], etc. 3.5.1 Size effect The product selectivity of Ru-based catalysts is related to Ru loading, surface Ru sites, support particle size and catalyst pretreatment conditions. Ja Hun Kwak et al. explored the catalytic performance of 0.1∼5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation [133]. At low Ru loading (≤ 0.5 %), Ru existed as highly dispersed atoms with high CO selectivity. As the metal loading increased, Ru atoms formed 3D metal clusters with increased selectivity for CH4 and decreased selectivity for CO generation. Yan et al. prepared Ru/Al2O3 catalysts with different Ru structural configurations by controlling the mass loading of Ru on Al2O3 and explored their catalytic pathways [136]. It was indicated that the CO selectivity decreased continuously with increasing Ru content. Further theoretical calculations showed that single Ru sites favored the RWGS path with lower energy barriers, while 3D Ru nanoclusters favored the methanation path, mainly because the RuOAl interface formed by monolayer Ru atoms and Al2O3 promoted the RWGS reaction. Ali M. Abdel-Mageed et al. systematically investigated the effects of support particle size on the catalytic performance of Ru/TiO2 catalysts [138]. As shown in Fig. 9 a, catalysts with large TiO2 particle sizes exhibited 100 % selectivity for CO2 methanation. In contrast, catalysts with small TiO2 particle sizes had 100 % selectivity for RWGS reaction. Comprehensive characterization of the catalysts showed that changes in support size affected the structure, oxidation state, and electronic state of the catalysts, such as increase the density of oxygen vacancies and Ti3+ (Fig. 9b), and changes in the percentage of oxidic Ru3+ (Fig. 9c), which affected the catalytic performance of the catalysts. Aisulu Aitbekova et al. used CeO2-supported homogeneous Ru nanoparticle catalysts with controlled particle size to explore the effect of pretreatment conditions on product selectivity [134]. The results showed that after reduction pretreatment in H2, the Ru nanoparticles on CeO2 supports were unchanged, resulting in a selective methanation catalyst; after oxidation pretreatment at a lower temperature (210 °C) in O2, the initial Ru nanoparticles were redispersed into atomically dispersed RuOx species, which were more selective to produce CO (> 90 % CO selectivity) via the RWGS reaction. 3.5.2 Metal doping The addition of alkali metal promoters to Ru-based catalysts can tune the selectivity of CO2 hydrogenation, thus facilitating the RWGS reaction. Raimundo C. Rabelo-Neto et al. added Na to Ru/m-ZrO2 catalysts to explore the catalytic mechanism and the product distribution [140]. The results of CO2-TPD and DRIFTS (Fig. 9d and 9e) showed that increasing the Na loading increased the alkalinity of the catalyst, which weakened the CH bond strength of adsorbed CO. Therefore, formation of CH bonds of formate intermediates in RWGS was accelerated, and promoted the formation of CO at the Ru/m-ZrO2 interface. In addition, Na tended to cover the Ru0 which were noted to be the site of methanation. Therefore, the addition of Na was reported to inhibit the methanation reaction and promote the RWGS reaction. Doping with Si elements also changed the product selectivity of Ru-based catalysts. Cisneros et al. doped Si into Ru/TiO2 to explore its catalyst structure and products [139]. The results showed that the high-temperature treatment of Ru/TiO2 in the reaction atmosphere led to a change in selectivity from methanation to CO generation via the RWGS reaction. Si-doped Ru/TiO2 supports maintained high CH4 selectivity and stability after the same treatment with an optimum loading of about 8 wt%. Ru-based catalysts also suffered from issues risk of sintering at high temperatures. To improve the sintering resistance, Tang et al. prepared H-SiO2@Ru@SiO2 by encapsulating 1 nm-sized Ru clusters in hollow silicon shells [143]. The space-constrained structure prevented the sintering of Ru clusters, and the permeable SiO2 layer allowed the diffusion of gaseous reactants and products. The catalyst with reduced Ru particle size exhibited excellent RWGS activity, near 100 % CO selectivity (Table 5), and long-term stability at 200∼500 °C. 3.6 Ir-based catalysts Compared with other noble metals, the studies of Ir-based catalysts for RWGS reaction were less performed. Most of the research was focused on exploring the effect of Ir dispersion CO selectivity [95,146–148]. Chen et al. compared the selectivity of 1 wt% Ir/TiO2 and Ir1/TiO2 and demonstrated that the product selectivity was closely related to the particle size [147]. Ir nanoparticles exhibited strong CO bond-breaking ability and showed high CH4 selectivity. As the particle size of Ir decreased to a single atom, its ability to break CO bonds was significantly reduced. In addition, the activation energy for the formation of CH4 was dramatically increased, causing high CO selectivity (Fig. 10 a∼c). Li et al. explored the RWGS reaction on Ir NPs/CeO2 [146]. They found that the dispersion and chemical structure of Ir components in the catalyst were significant to the catalytic activity, and the product selectivity in the RWGS reaction could be adjusted by changing the Ir loadings. As shown in Fig. 10d, when Ir loading in the Ir/CeO2 catalyst was decreased from 20 % to 5 %, CO selectivity increased from 12 % to nearly 100 %. The smaller Ir nanoparticles possessed more low-coordinated atoms and showed higher catalytic activity. Moreover, the regulation of the chemical state of the Ir components by strong metal-support interactions also had a critical impact on the product selectivity of the RWGS reaction. The metallic Ir was selective for CH4, while partically oxidized Ir was conducive to the formation of CO (Fig. 10e and f). Table 6 gives the recent advances of Ir-based catalysts in RWGS. 4 Conclusions and perspectives CO2 hydrogenation to value-added chemicals is considered as a promising approach to reducing carbon emissions. However, high energy barrier from inherent inertness of CO2 molecules (∆G 0 = −394.38 kJ/mol) poses great challenge in the activation and transformation of CO2, hindering the versatile application of CO2 utilization. CO2 hydrogenation is kinetically unfavorable at low temperatures, and requires a high temperature to activate the CO2 molecule. On the other hand, most CO2 hydrogenation reactions (for example, the transformation of CO2 to methanol) are exothermic reactions, and it is thermodynamically unfavorable at high temperature. Thus, a moderate temperature is necessary to balance the kinetic and thermodynamic limitations. Among the approaches to transform CO2, CO2 hydrogenation to CO in particular has gained much attention because it is an endothermic reaction which makes it both kinetically and thermodynamically favorable at high temperatures. This review highlighted the recent progress of noble metals in thermal CO2 hydrogenation to CO. The structure-performance relationship and strategies to modulate the activity, selectivity, and stability of the supported noble catalysts were thoroughly presented. The influence of oxygen vacancies, support, transition metal oxide promoter, core-shell structure, metal dispersion, and hydroxyl groups on the RWGS was also critically reviewed. Extensive research efforts have been made in this area according to the literature; however, future efforts should be devoted to the following direction to facilitate the growth of this area. (1) Synthesis of atomically dispersed metal catalysts with high stability is challenging. According to the current literature, atomically dispersed noble metals showed better CO selectivity than metal nanoparticle counterparts because of the weak binding of CO on highly dispersed metals and poor H2 association ability of isolated metal atoms. However, the atomically dispersed metal atoms, in general, suffered from issues of sintering or aggregation at high temperatures as the CO2 hydrogenation to CO is kinetically and thermodynamically favorable at high temperatures. Besides, the product H2 could further facilitate the aggregation progress. Effective approaches to fabricating highly stable catalysts with atomically dispersed metal species are urgently needed. Confining the metal atoms within porous support such as zeolite could be one of the possible strategies. (2) The characterization of catalysts under reaction conditions is critical. Unveiling the structure-performance relationship should be the prerequisite for guiding the design of high-performance RWGS catalysts. Most of the current research failed to characterize the structure of catalysts under reactions. Since structure reconstruction could easily happen at high temperatures, and the reactant or product could induce changes in the active site structure, ex-situ characterization of catalysts cannot accurately disclose the true structure of the active sites. This limitation makes the study of structure-performance relationship unreliable. (3) Machine-learning approach could be applied for guiding the design of new catalysts for RWGS. Traditionally, the development of catalysts was based on a trial-and-error approach. However, in recent decades, the rapid growth of data sciences has enabled for discovery of underlying correlations based on existing knowledge or information. It was reported that an automatic machine-learning framework, capable of guiding itself to find desired catalysts, has been developed. [149]. In contrast to the conventional computing approach that relies on hard-coded instructions offered by experts, the developed machine-learning platform taught itself by absorbing existing knowledge through algorithms. However, machine-learning guided development of high-performance catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to CO is still in its initial stages, and further efforts are required in this direction. Critical parameters, such as the d-band center (εd), metal electronegativity (χM), and valence electron number of metal atoms (M V) could be the possible key descriptors for CO2 hydrogenation to CO. coredata.dc:description: CO2 hydrogenation is one of the pivotal approaches to minimizing CO2 emission. As a critical step in converting CO2 into renewable fuels or industrial products, CO2 hydrogenation to CO via reverse water gas shift (RWGS) has received widespread attention and research activities. As a cornerstone of CO2 catalytic utilization, the properties of catalysts play a critical role in determining the catalytic performance. Supported noble metal catalysts have been widely explored in this reaction but designing a catalyst that possesses high activity, decent stability, and good selectivity at low temperature. Herein, a critical review of the advances in supported noble metal catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to CO is presented. Particular attention was made to the structure-performance relationship and strategies to enhance the catalytic behavior of noble metals while also exploring the reaction mechanisms in detail. This review aims to provide an overview and guidelines for the design of stable and efficient supported noble catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to CO in the future.
coredata.dc:title: Supported noble metal-based catalysts for thermal CO2 hydrogenation to CO
